Comment:
Hi everyone!

My 30th game with Master Freddy and still no luck.  Freddy springs on me another unusual opening, this time called The Bronstein Gambit after he kicks off with 1. d4.
2.  ..... g4 - here is the Bronstein Gambit, looking to get a rook on g1 putting pressure on the g file should Henry castle there perhaps?
2.  ..... g4 - here is the Bronstein Gambit, looking to get a rook on g1 putting pressure on the g file should Henry castle there perhaps?
3. e4 - Freddy now grabs the centre after I decide to accept the gambit.
3. e4 - Freddy now grabs the centre after I decide to accept the gambit.
4. ...... e5 - I now contest the centre, looks a bit like a Philidor's Defense.
4. ...... e5 - I now contest the centre, looks a bit like a Philidor's Defense.

14. Be3 - just look at that d6 pawn my friends.

15. a3 - I was expecting Bxc5 here given that the bishop on d7 is only defended once, and you will only need one guess as to just who is defending it!  Still, Freddy must have something else up his sleeve.

15. a3 - I was expecting Bxc5 here given that the bishop on d7 is only defended once, and you will only need one guess as to just who is defending it!  Still, Freddy must have something else up his sleeve.
15. ....... Qb6 - Glenda defends that c5 pawn but also puts pressure on b2.  If that c3 horsie should move away next turn ......
16. e5 - here is another move I was dreading though, I cannot take the e5 pawn because that will be the end of Fou Leblanc on d7.  Fou Leblanc challenges his counterpart on the h1-a8 diagonal.
18. Qxd5 - a piece trade and now the Wicked Witch of the West burrows into my position.  I now protect the b7 pawn.

21. ...... Na6?? - Freddy has regained his pawn, now I make a wrong choice with a knight move, in hindsight e6 would have been better.  Ten moves down the line I am gonna get Freddied again!  Now how could this happen?  Henry looks safely tucked away on the kingside does he not?
